byline.original: By ROSS PARMENTER Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: When "Gone With the Wind" reopens at Loew's State tomorrow, timed to the year of the Civil War centennial, it brings with it an impressive array of statistics. The rights to Margaret Mitchell's novel of the Old South were bought by David O. Selznick...
docs.lead_paragraph: When "Gone With the Wind" reopens at Loew's State tomorrow, timed to the year of the Civil War centennial, it brings with it an impressive array of statistics. The rights to Margaret Mitchell's novel of the Old South were bought by David O. Selznick for $50,000, up to that time the highest price ever paid by a motion-picture producer for a first novel, and that was only the first of many records it has broken.
